Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic, thank you for the welcome.  Trying to keep focused but sometimes just lose it.  I also have an appointment confirmed with the oncologist tomorrow so I will have a plan of action.  I think I will type it up and pin it somewhere so I can mark off each session.  I see others on the site have done this.  I just want it to start now and get rid of this "thing" in me.  I am not very patient at the best of times :( x
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Thanks Annie for your kind words.  That's a brilliant idea.  I am already repeating myself and I am on FB so will use Messenger or WhatsApp and add people from there.  It is comforting to know there are people on the other side that can help.  I'm not used to asking for help so I need to change that too!  I've got a full day of tests tomorrow and was going to go on my own but I think I will ask my other half to come with me.  Most of it will be sitting around waiting for dye to disperse itself but even if we can nip out for a walk and come back in. I'm sick of sitting around already and my treatment hasn't even started.  x
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Thanks Aspen. Yes, I feel as if I keep the door closed it won't get worse!  Mad I know.  I'm fine messaging people but when somebody calls me, I'm off.  It's almost like I'm embarrassed I've got cancer.  It's such a horrible word. How did your first chemo go?  Are you trying the ice cap thing?  That's another thing that's freaking me.  I've got short hair but the thought of losing it isn't great.  How many sessions/weeks is your chemo lasting for?  That's why I'm getting the chemo too so the surgery should be less intrusive and the tumour smaller.  I was trying to soak in all the information but some has seeped back out!  I shall be more attentive tomorrow and take a notebook.  I actually had the notebook with me but just stared at it and the the surgeon wrote down the type of cancer I have as I must have been staring at him vacantly! Thank you xx
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Back from my tests.  Hospital were really quick.  Even managed to get out for an hour's walk in between my dye taking effect for the MRI scan. I now know what you mean about a folder.  Came back with a bag-full of leaflets on ice caps, wigs.  Now have a box file to hold them in. What are your side effects as far as the chemo go?  Hopefully get my plan of action tonight for care pathway stuff. Feeling calmer today - not quite sure why! x
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Thank you walkergirl.  I work in a large office for quite a lot of people so my direct bosses have alerted them.  Everybody has been sending me some lovely messages.  Luckily I can work from home which I think will be a godsend once the chemo starts as it's a big open plan office and there's always somebody ill so I can avoid the germs :)  I feel it's better for people to know as it's not just a shock for me but also them so I'm hoping makes it easier for me to deal with.  Just heard that I have an appointment with the oncologist tomorrow night so so a plan of action will begin.  Mavi
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi Aspen, I think you are completely correct re the stress.  It has to have had some effect on me.  Bosses are all being lovely to me now - strangely enough - but I really don't think they've got a clue how I've been feeling this year.  Nearly 23 years in the same company and the past year has been my worst.  Thankfully, I've a lot of good friends work beside me who have kept me sane and are probably now going to keep me sane again. It's "me" time now so they can sling their hook. My new stroppy attitude for 2018 is beginning early .....
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hope all goes well tonight.  I can understand that.  It's good to have some time to think on your own too xx
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Thank you. Both kindles. Is being charged x
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Thank you!x
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hullo. Newbie arrived. Called back for unclear standard mammogram last Tuesday. Three hours of tests. Ultrasound. Biopsies. Suction. You name it. Results back yesterday. One lump. One lymph node affected. Full MOT at hospital on Thursday. Bone scan. Liver scan. CT. MRI.  See oncologist on Thursday night. Very emotional. Crying at everything. Even random adverts on TV. Tough road ahead with meds, chemo, lumpectomy then radiotherapy. Don’t want to face friends but know I need support. Shit
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Thank you.  Just asked him to come along with me.  I feel bad as it's a whole day of sitting around.  I think the tests themselves are quick but all the faff that goes along with it not so quick. Not a big fan of Xmas at the best of times.  Hate the fact it's one day but seems to go on for months.  Don't even get me started on that one!  I'm a bigger Bah Humbug than usual as I would normally be getting my results on Mon/Tue next week and Xmas is just getting right in the way! xx
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Thank you. Wigs sound interesting. I was joking with my friend saying I would get a long one as my hair is pretty short. Then I would really freak people out! Good you can order a few to see what you like best.  4 April doesn’t seem too long. I will be the same after my chemo. Probably expecting my arm to fall off and wondering why it’s not!  I’ll keep you updated. Xx
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: I'll see how I am today with all the tests.  Sometimes I feel a bit numb with it all but I think that's just natural.  My brain trying to digest it as best it can.  I wonder what sets these things off.  I've had a pretty stressful year at work with lots of changes going on and part of me wants to blame them for putting me through it but I am not sure there's much evidence of stress causing cancer.  It's all a but of an unknown.  Sounds identical to me!  I'm off shortly to hospital for my day out getting scans.  I really know how to celebrate Xmas ! xx
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Ah yes they warned me about taste tonight. Said I might go off chocolate or red wine. All my scans and X-rays came back clear from earlier today which has boosted me a bit.  Basically appx 6 months chemo, op and the 1 month of radiotherapy plus rest in between. It will be a long 9 months but hopefully light st the end. I have to keep thinking that we were supposed to be away in January but holiday to be cancelled. Want to get chemo started for better or worse.  I will stock up on the sherbet lemons.  I hope the next chemo is better and your body gets used to it.   Dotx
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi Smoo, welcome.  I am a newbie too.  I have cried loads since I was diagnosed on 18 December.  Angry at myself for getting cancer, angry at myself for crying too much.  I now have a treatment plan and start my chemo on 11 Jan.  I don't think 2018 is going to be my favourite year but hoping the end of it will be a new beginning - even at 53!  I am a little calmer now I'm getting my head around it all but it's people being nice to me that can set me off.  I don't want people to feel sorry for me.  I want them to fight for me too.  It's difficult for friends around to understand how you feel.   They don't know what to say or what to do.  This is why this site is great.  We all feel the same and we understand.  I'm trying to stay positive, I'm looking to the future.  I want to get through this.  In my mind, if I think negatively, my body will react negatively.  I've been trying to carry on as best I can.  At the gym loads. For some reason, if I run on the treadmill, I think I can run it out of me.  Silly, but it seems to help.  Headphones on and try not to think of anything.  Obviously, once my treatment starts, that will be out of the window but at the moment, it's getting me through it.  Keep positive, stay focused.  We can do this.  Dot xx
Posts.Title: New to this group

Posts.Content: Thanks Sue. It is surreal. I feel so normal and healthy. I wake up in the morning and remember  I’ve got cancer. Maybe your crying will come later. Every time I speak to someone new about it, it sets me off. It is getting better.  51 will have to be your new 50 Please drop me a line whenever you feel the need.  I am also finding the site really helpful.  I am so glad everyone is here. It is great to have people who know what we are going through and also to hear how other people feel   Lots of hugs and tears and smiles Dot xx
Posts.Title: New to this group

Posts.Content: Thank you!  I don't feel very resilient at the moment but I am keen to get it all started.   Xmas just got right in the way or I am sure I would have been on the chemo already.  It's the thought of it getting worse because nothing is happening that's the scary bit.  I see it as a little devil sitting there thinking, ha ha, they have found me but they're not giving her treatment yet, I will just get bigger and show them.  I am trying to see chemo as the good guy - strangely! Dot x
Posts.Title: New to this group

Posts.Content: Thank you for putting my mind at ease.  I feel like it's an alien!  Well, it is sort of. Dotx
Posts.Title: New to this group

Posts.Content: Hi Fishywishy, welcome.  You well find lots of help and support from the site here.  I was just diagnosed on 18 December and went through all the crying.  Got fed up with myself crying everytime somebody send me a message. I've not heard of Paget's disease.  Hope it all goes well for you.  First insinct is to want rid.  I have been fit and healthy all my life, on no medication until this little blighter came along.  I hope by the end of 2018 I will be cancer-free and ready to come back out of limbo land and live again!  Feeling a bit stir crazy not getting out the house as much as I would like.  So used to walking daily with my friends at work.  Miss their company and our lunch time moans about work in general.  Still, they are keeping in touch and up-to-date and I am still working as best I can although only just started chemo, so not sure how practical that will be.  I am staying optimistic and already trying to ascertain how many holidays I can carry forward to next year!   Always hopeful. Good luck to you too. Keep in touch. Dot xx
Posts.Title: New to this group

Posts.Content: Time always seems to fly by for everything else.  Just typical.  Still we are now into January so we are getting nearer.  I wish you well with your surgery and your biopsy.  Baby steps and we will get there.  I have been working from home today.  I work in a huge open plan office so have decided to avoid it at all costs.  Every week someone else is off with another sickness or flu bug.  I am trying to keep as healthy as possible.  Made a huge pot of mixed veg soup which will last weeks.  Have frozen them in takeaway containers from the Chinese!  Just need to finish off the Xmas chocolates .... It's the being up and down like a yo yo that is horrible.  Fine and then like a black pit has descended into my stomach.  Trying to snap out of it. Keep me posted Good luck Dotx
Posts.Title: New to this group

Posts.Content: Hi JET999 I had my first round of chemo on 23 January and used the cold cap.  Managed to sit with it on for 3 hours but it wasn't pleasant.  I had a couple of terrible headaches, felt queasy the night of the chemo and pretty dizzy for the first 8-9 days and spaced out. At that point, I didn't know whether this was the cold cap, or the chemo!  I had my second round of chemo on Tuesday and made the decison not to use the cold cap as my hair is falling out anyway.  I have had no headaches,  not queasy and not dizzy. Actually feeling pretty ok so I think I have made the right decision for me. Everybody is different though.  There was a man sitting next to me on Tuesday who didn't seem to be bothering too much at all about it. My hair is almost gone, just like a newborn now!  I can't quite get the courage to shave it off but I am putting my wig on today for the first time.  I actually really like the wig but I think it's just that initial step of walking out the door with it on that's getting at me! Mavi (Dot xx)
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and cold caps

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear you feeling so down.  I hope today is a brighter day for you.  We all have off days and it's allowed.  Let's hope 2018 is a good year for us all.
Posts.Title: New year, feeling blue

Posts.Content: I haven't posted for a while but keep my eye on things every so often.  Now finished FEC and Paclitaxol, tumour removed and 3 lymph nodes removed. Suffered from a seroma at the site of the lymph node removal and had to be drained twice.  Felt like I had a tennis ball under my arm!  Port also removed - yay!  Arm still doesn't feel right and now 3 weeks after surgery.  Numb feeling and can't quite straighten.  Been up at hospital today to get "measured" for Radiotheraphy and tattoos now in place.  Start on 2 August for 20 sessions altogether. Weird, oncologist advises that she is really pleased with my results.  Tumour gone completely but can't quite get that feeling of joy I thought I would have.  Still cancer cells in my body.  Obviously now to be targeted by 20 sessions of RT.  They've said it's in remission but I wanted to hear "that's you cancer clear".  I am sure there will always be a niggle at the back of my mind - will it come back - but I will remain positive. Still on Herceptin until Feb 2019 and now also being prescribed Zometa for 3 years.  I will get this every 6 months.  It's to stop osteoporosis  as the RT breaks down the cell structure.  Also to get prescription for calcium.  Still, getting there.  Hoping that I get that "all clear" later on in the year.  To be honest, my journey with cancer has flown by.  When I was diagnosed in December 2017, I thought it would drag. I suppose having so many appointments, things to try and remember to add to your diary, cures for side effects, it's been pretty hectic. I am still off work.  Managed to work through FEC but finished at the start of April.  Not quite sure when I will go back.  Certainly not until after the Herceptin has finished in Feb.  I want sometime for "ME" once all the medication stops.  I want to be free to do what I want to do and not go to the chemist, go the hospital, inject myself to stop blood clotting etc, etc.  Might even get myself on that Indian Head Massage course I've been looking to do and try my hand at some silver jewellery making.  A new me will emerge :) For those starting their journey, good luck and for those coming to the end, I hope it's not been too bad for you either. Mavi (Dot x)
Posts.Title: RT about to start

Posts.Content: Hi all, not updated for a while due to complications but nothing to do with chemo! Finished my 3 x FEC.  Ended up with terrible diarrhoea which I thought was a side effect.  Sample handed into doc and advised I have had food poisoning.  Either ecoli or Salmonella.  Another sample gone in last week to check the position.  Wonderful!  One weekend feeling great, go out with friends and then end up sicker than chemo side effects.  Spent a week on the settee and ended up getting a blood clot in my leg.  Honestly, could write a book!  I have had a clot before and have a condition called Protein S Deficiency which means my blood can be prone to clotting even though I am injecting myself with blood thinner daily.  Ended up at the Western last Saturday for 4 1/2 hours with some really unwell people sitting around me which didn't help.  Back on Sunday to get ultrasound and confirmed clot in the back of my calf.  Now upped my daily injection levels to help dissolve the clot. Have now started my new cycle of Perjeta, Herceptin and Paclitaxel.    So I get the Paclitaxel weekly and the Perjeta (only 3 of these in total) with Herceptin every third week.  I believe Herceptin will be for a year in total.  I may get my port removed after the Perjeta and Paclitaxel are finished.  The Herceptin can be given as an injection in the leg so I will do a trial round of one and then decide whether I will get my port removed and continue with leg injections for the remaining period. Good news is the Oncologist has agreed I can go on holiday at the end of May.  I am over-excited to say the least.  Spent the last two days getting quotes for travel insurance which has been interesting.  First quote was £800 for a 2 week holiday in Greece!!  Some won't even insure if awaiting any kind of surgery.  Even though I am getting my lumpectomy in July.  Quite bizarre. Managed to get one for £88 which is double the price we paid for a yearly world-wide policy before I was diagnosed but worth it to get away. Choked with the cold yesterday but on the mend today.  Keep strong all. Mavi (Dot) xxxx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn, that's weird isn't it?  Yes, the first time I found out I got the clot sitting on one of these little deck chairs with the metal bar across the front - 9 years ago.  They tested my blood and found the Protein S.  Put me on Warfarin for 6 months but luckily took me back off.  Got my sexy socks to wear on flights but have a slightly allergy to nylon so they do make my legs itch.  Definitely considering the removal for the Herceptin.  I think I will still have to heard to the chemo unit for my Herceptin as it appears to take 15 minutes for the injection.  I shall ask some questions when I am nearing the end of my other treatment and see what is best. Thank you! Dot xx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi LiziX I just started my Perjeta, Paclitaxel and Herceptin last week and ok so far.  My Paclitaxel is weekly and I had another one yesterday.  I get the Perjeta and Herceptin every 3rd week.  I've already come through 3 x FEC so hoping this one goes ok too.  I was given anti sickness, steriod and Piritin before the Paclitaxel yesterday but didn't need to take any more anti sickness.  Been feeling fine.  I believe, for my treatment, it just a case of keeping my drugs up to the same level at all times so hoping I won't feel any different.  I've been for a Reiki treatment this morning as I'm awake around 1330 with the steriods.  Only last for 3 days but getting it weekly will make this tiring.  I plan to nap when my body needs it but carry on with life as usual.  I hope to get to the gym to a gentle stretch class on Friday.  Not usually my scene as I like to feel like I've done something but at least it will be change of scenery!  If it's too easy, I'll try and have a cycle. Try and do what you normally do with loads of fresh air thrown in to help!  Take care and will be thinking of you. Difficult to say try not to worry too much.  Take each day as it comes and make the most of the good days Mavi (Dot xx)
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***
